title-group.article-title: Rigid polyurethane foams obtained from tall oil and filled with natural fibers: Application as a support for immobilization of lignin-degrading microorganisms

article-meta.aff: 1Polymer Laboratory, Latvian State Institute of Wood Chemistry, Riga, Latvia
2Department of Applied Biology, University of Almeria, Almeria, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Ugis Cabulis, Latvian State Institute of Wood Chemistry, Dzerbenes 27, LV-1006, Riga, Latvia. Email: cabulis@edi.lv

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The forest biomass represents an abundant, renewable, non-food competition, and low-cost resource that can play an alternative role to petro-resources. The first topic of the research activity is focused on the use of wood and a pulp mill by-product—tall oil —as raw materials for the production of rigid polyurethane foams. The maximum content of the renewable resource in ready foams is 26%. By using biopolymers as a matrix, a natural way is to reinforce them with natural fibers. Further advantages are significant weight and cost savings and, at the same time, replacement of petrochemical raw materials. Three different natural fibers (cellulose, wood, and modified cellulose) were tested as a filler of foams. Rigid polyurethane foams was used as biomass support particles for immobilization of microorganisms. Suspension cultures of the organism with biomass support particles can promote the adhesion of cells to the porous matrix surface, and subsequently the cells become immobilized during the cultivation. This method for cell immobilization has a great potential for enhancing the production of proteins or chemicals in culture supernatants. The presence of natural fibers in the matrix promotes the enzyme production because the material not only functions as an attachment place but also supplies some nutrients to the microorganism and induces the production of ligninolytic enzymes. This paper discusses the studies into the use of tall oil as a renewable source in rigid polyurethane foam production

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rigid polyurethane (PUR) foam is one of the most important insulating materials used today in the construction industry and is the main insulation material used in the global appliances (refrigerators, freezers, etc.) industry. A general review of the PUR industry and the physics of heat transfer in cellular materials can be found.1,2 Today, these foams are based on polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (polymeric MDI) and either polyether or polyester polyols.

Polyols with renewable carbon content are polyols that incorporate significantly higher levels of renewable-based raw materials than the conventional polyols made almost entirely from petrochemicals. To be considered a natural oil polyol (NOP), at least one of the renewable raw materials is a vegetable oil derived from growing plants, for example from rapeseed,5–7 castor,6 and especially soya.8–11 Different types of by-products and waste materials are also used for PUR production, such as paper waste12 or a by-product of pulp mills—tall oil (TO).13,14 In the field of PU, NOPs have emerged as a hot topic in recent years as a result of growing interest within the global sustainability movement.15

The general aim of this work is different utilizations of forest raw resources or by-products of forest connected industries for the production of eco-compatible foams and composites suitable for many practical applications, with particular attention to the construction, packaging, and automotive sectors. The central topic of the research activity is focused on the use of wood, pulp, and paper mill by-products (bark, chips, sawdust, black liquor, and TO) as raw materials for the production of PUR by an innovative sustainable synthetic process with reduced energy consumption.

By using biopolymers as a matrix, a natural way is to reinforce them with biogenic or natural fibers (NFs). Further advantages are significant weight and cost savings (most cellulose fibers are cheaper and much lighter than glass fibers—approx. 1.5 g/cm3 compared with 2.6 g/cm3). For this reason, the relative properties of the bio-composites are often superior to those of glass fiber composites. In addition, NFs are combustible and biodegradable. However, NFs also have disadvantages, for instance, increased moisture absorption. The properties of NFs are affected by many factors, such as variety, climate, harvest, maturity, degree of retting, etc.16 There are investigations on PU resins filled with different fibers—sisal fibers17 and oil palm trunk fiber dust,18 but not so much on PUR—wood flour,9 wood and hemp fibers,19 cellulose fibers,20 and flax fibers.21

Among the large number of applications of PUR, their use in the biotechnological field as a support for the immobilization of enzymes and whole cells has recently emerged.22 The advantage of PUR for this purpose relies on the easy control of the pore size, stable maintenance of the quantity of cells and large-scale application at low price. In this work, PUR were used as biomass support particles (BSPs) for immobilization of the lignin-degrading fungus Phanerochaete flavido-alba. Lignin-degrading enzymes such as lignin peroxidase (LiP), manganese-dependent peroxidase (MnP), and laccase (Lac) are used in the diverse fields of industry and environment such as bioconversion of lignocelluloses into value added-products (e.g. biofuels and chemical feedstocks), pulp delignification, dye bleaching, detoxification of wastewaters, detergent manufacturing and transformation of antibiotics and steroids.23 Large-scale production of ligninolytic enzymes has been difficult owing to the sensitivity of the production organism to agitation. However, it has been shown that the immobilization of producing microorganism on PUR appears to stabilize the enzyme production system.24,25 The success of this step greatly depends on the composition and structure of the PUR. Here we analyze the effect of the PUR structure (open or closed cells) and the agent used as NFs reinforcement on LiP and Lac production by immobilized cultures of P. flavido-alba.
In the present article the perspective of PUR obtained from wood industry by-products and filled with NF, as a support for immobilization of enzymes is shown.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
Polyols on the basis of renewable natural oils, suitable for obtaining PUR, can be obtained by different methods. Most often the esterification or epoxidation of oils are applied. In the present work, for producing of PUR, polyols obtained by esterification and amidization of TO with triethanolamine and diethanolamine, correspondingly were used. Different grades of TO obtained from the company Forchem (Rauma, Finland) were used (Table 1) for the synthesis of polyols. Table 1.
Tall oil (TO) product parameters
TO Fatty acids, % Rosin acids, % Unsaponi- fiables, % Acid value, mgKOH/g Viscosity, at 20°C Density, kg/m3 Softening point, °C
FOR 2 97 1.8 1.3 197 30 904 –
FOR 10 87 10 3 194 50 920 –
FOR 20 76 20 3 190 70 930 –
FOR 25-30 70 25–30 3 190 85 945 –
FOR 90 3.5 92 3.9 178 – – 67
TO is a mix of different fatty (C12—C22) and rosin acids (C20); common samples are given: (a) fatty acid – oleic acid (C18H34O2); (b) rosin acid – abietic acid (C20H30O2) (1):

Firstly, optimum synthesis conditions of polyols suitable for obtaining PUR were determined. The synthesis process was controlled from the triethanolamine (acid value) or diethanolamine (acid value and NH value) conversion degree. It should be mentioned that the temperature in the esterification process is higher (170°C) than in the amidization process (145°C). The structure of polyols was characterized from Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy data, which were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer SpectrumOne (UK) spectrometer at a resolution of 4 cm−1, 32 scans. The IR data were collected using the attenuated total reflectance (ATR) technique with a ZnSe and diamond crystals.

The typical formulations used in this study were polyols from TO and a higher functional polyether polyol based on sorbitol Lupranol 3422 (it contains only secondary hydroxyl groups, OH Number 490 mg KOH/g)—from BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany). As additives’ surfactants, NIAX Silicone L620 and L6915, correspondingly for open and closed foam structures, were used. The catalysts were NIAX Catalyst E-A-1 (all NIAX products from Momentive Performance Materials (Columbus, USA)) and Polycat 5 (from Air Products (Utrecht, the Netherlands)). As an isocyanate, polymeric diphenylmethane diisocyanate—IsoPMDI 92140—supplied by BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany) was used.

The NFs utilized in the study were wood fibers from LaSole (Percoto, Italy) and cellulose fibers from Retenmaier (Rosenberg, Germany). A biologically modified sample of cellulose fibers was also used. Modified cellulose was obtained by treatment of the same cellulose fibers with a lignocellulolytic fungus. Cellulose fibers were inoculated with the fungus and incubated for 21 days at 30°C as earlier reported.26 Characteristics of the fibers are given in Table 2, and the shape characteristics of the fibers are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of fibers: (a) cellulose; (b) wood; (c) modified cellulose. Table 2.
Characteristics of the fibers used in the study
Fiber Supplier Water content, % Wax, % Lignin, % OH content, % Dimensions L, m Dimensions L, m Aspect ratio
Cellulose Retenmaier 4.5 0.9 28.7 322 363 64 6.7
Wood LaSole 4.9 3.5 29.6 244 286 80 5.5

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: PUR samples were obtained by mechanically mixing appropriate amounts of IsoPMDI 92140 and the polyol system (polyols, surfactant, catalysts, blowing agent, and NFs) for 10–15 s. The unreacted mixture was poured into a plastic mould (20 × 30 × 10 cm) for free foaming. The polymerization reaction took place at room temperature for all obtained samples and was completed in about 3–5 min; the samples were conditioned before tests for 24 h. The content of different components in the composites was calculated on the basis of initial weights.

sec.title: PUR characterization methods
sec.p: The physical and mechanical properties of the foams were measured in accordance with the following standards: foam density—DIN 53420; compressive strength—DIN 53421; closed cell content—ISO 4590; and water absorbance after 7 days—DIN 53428. The compressive strength of PUR was tested parallel and perpendicular to foam rise. Mechanical testing of PUR was performed on testing machines Zwick/Roell 500 N and Zwick/Roell Z100 (Ulm, Germany). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was applied to obtain photographs of unfilled and NF-filled foams (SEM microscope—Tescan TS 5634, Brno, Czech Republic).

sec.title: Immobilization of the fungus on PUR
sec.p: The microorganism used in this study was Phanerochaete flavido-alba ATCC 60998.

Eight different PUR with a density of 45 kg/m3 were used as a support for fungal cell immobilization. They included foams with open or closed cells, each without NF reinforcement or reinforced with 9% of cellulose, wood, or modified cellulose.

Prior to use, the foams were rinsed with 70% (v/v) ethanol for 1 h and washed thoroughly three times with distilled water. The foams were then dried and five pieces (2 × 2 × 1 cm) were weighed and placed in a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask containing 50 mL of potato dextrose broth. After sterilization (121°C, 20 min), the flask was inoculated with two 1 cm2 plugs of a 7-days-old culture of fungi on potato dextrose agar. A control without PUR was included as a free-cell culture reference. Incubation was done in triplicate at 30°C without shaking. Conidiospores attached easily to the PUR and growth took place throughout most of the support after 11 days (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Method for immobilization of P. flavido-alba on PUR. Material was cut into pieces and placed on 250 mL flasks. Immobilization of the microorganism on the PUR support was complete after 11 days and then the immobilized culture was incubated with the enzyme production medium for 13 days.

For enzyme production, the immobilized cultures were exposed to a medium amended with an inducer for lignin-degrading enzyme production. The total liquid volume of immobilized cultures was aseptically decanted and the flasks were re-filled with 25 mL of a fresh enzyme production medium (in g/L: 10 g glucose, 5 g peptone, 2 g yeast extract, 0.55 g ABTS (2'-azinobis-(3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonate), and 70 mL of trace element solution27). Cultures were incubated at 30°C without shaking for 13 days. Lignin-degrading enzymes (Lac and LiP) were analyzed in the extracellular culture (Figure 2).

Lignin peroxidase (LiP) was determined by the peroxide-dependent oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde.28 Laccase (Lac) was analyzed by monitoring the oxidation of syringaldazine.29 Enzymatic activity was expressed in U/L with 1 U defined as 1 µmol of the substrate oxidized per min. All chemicals were from Sigma-Aldrich.

Growth was measured in terms of the dry weight of the mycelium after it was dried overnight at 105°C. An average predetermined foam cube dry weight was subtracted from the weight of the foam plus mycelium.

SEM was conducted to evaluate the fungal growth pattern in the foam. Briefly, samples were dried at 40°C for 5 days, after which they were coated with gold.30 Photomicrographs of the samples were then taken using an SEM (Hitachi S-3500, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: Polyol synthesis
sec.p:
The developed esterification and amidization technologies of the laboratory synthesis of polyols turned to be fully suitable in conditions of industrial production. In both cases, the synthesis process was controlled from the change of the acid value and diethanolamine conversion degree in the amidization process (Figure 3(a) and (b)). The characteristics of the obtained polyols are given in Tables 3 and 4. Figure 3.
(a) Esterification process kinetics, TO FOR 20, 170°C; (b) Amidization process kinetics, TO FOR 20, 145°C. Table 3.
Polyols of tall oil (TO) and triethanolamine. Esterification process. Ratio: OH/COOH = 2.30; temperature: 170°C
Polyols Rosin acid content, % Acid value, mg KOH/g OH value, mg KOH/g Viscosity at 25 C, mPa s Density, kg/m3
TOEst2 2 4.67 362 182 982
TOEst10 10 1.73 327 a a
TOEst20 20 1.29 350 a a
TOEst30 30 1.45 330 a a
TOEst90 90 14.0 244 Very viscous –
a
Crystals inside the polyol at 25°C (at the temperature >40°C crystals melt).
Table 4.
Polyols of tall oil (TO) and diethanolamine. Amidization process. Ratio: OH/COOH = 2.30; temperature 145°C
Polyols Rosin acid content, % Acid value, mg KOH/g OH value, mg KOH/g NH value, mgKOH/g Viscosity at 25 C, mPa s Density, kg/m3
TOAm2 2 2.70 289 46 612 971
TOAm10 10 1.85 286 51 754 979
TOAm20 20 1.84 258 53 1041 987
TOAm30 30 4.90 257 54 1772 992
TOAm90 90 31.6 225 – solid –

FTIR spectra (Figure 4(a) and (b)) show that, in the amidization process, polyols with a high absorption intensity of C = O groups at 1617 cm−1 are obtained, which is characteristic of tertiary amide, but in the esterification process, there is only an absorption peak at 1721 cm−1, which is characteristic of H-free ester groups, but there is the absence of the tertiary amide group peak. The end product of the amidization process is characterized by the balance between the amide type and ester type polyols (2): Figure 4.
Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of ready polyols: (a) diethanolamine and tall oil (TO) polyols (amidization process); (b) triethanolamine and TO polyols (esterification process).
As we looked only for qualitative evaluations of FTIR spectra, they are not extra-treated and not normalized to baseline.

sec.title: PUR production
sec.p:
For further experiments, the TO polyol obtained in the amidization process from FOR20 TO (rosin acid content 20%) was used, named as TOAm20. Two types of foams were obtained: closed cell and open cell foams with a density of 45 ± 5 kg/m3 and isocyanate index for both 125; in parallel series of experiments, the foams were filled with NF: cellulose, wood, and modified cellulose in concentrations of up to 9% (Table 5). Table 5.
Compositions for the preparation of foams for immobilization experiments
Component Closed cell foams Open cell foams
pbw pbw
TOAm20 85 85
Lupranol 3422 10 10
Glycerol 5 5
Water – 3
c-pentane 13 –
EA-1 0.2 0.2
Polycat 5 0.2 0.2
K Ac 0.2 0.4
L6915 1.5 –
L620 – 1.5
% in ready foams % in ready foams
NF 0 … 9 0 … 9
Isocyanate index Isocyanate index
IsoPMDI 92140 125 125
Foam characteristics
Closed cell content, % 92 ± 3 10 ± 2
Content of renewable raw material in ready foams, % 26.8 … 32.0 24.9 … 27.7
Figure 5 shows the SEMs of the closed cell rigid foams obtained from TO polyols and filled with NF, foam density 45 ± 5 kg/m3.

Parallel to the foaming direction, the cell structures are oriented vertically; in general, the foam has a closed cell structure, with average cell dimensions of 535 µm vertically and 255 µm horizontally for unfilled PUR. The addition of NF to the formulation is responsible for the increase of the viscosity of the polyol composition. This is a reason why the foam structures of filled foams are more uneven, and the cell dimensions are higher. The anisotropy of foams is confirmed by physical mechanical tests (Figure 6), and the anisotropy factor is approx. 2, both from cell size measurements in SEM and from compression tests. Figure 5.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) micrographs of the foams obtained from the tall oil (TO polyol filled with natural fibers (NFs), parallel to foaming direction: (a) unfilled polyol; (b) filled with wood 9%; (c) filled with cellulose 9%; and (d) filled with modified cellulose 9%. Figure 6.
Compression tests of PUR filled with natural fibers (NFs): (a) Young’s modulus and (b) compression strength.

sec.title: Enzyme production by the immobilized fungus on PUR
sec.p:
Table 6 shows the production of Lac and LiP by P. flavido-alba on immobilized cultures with different materials employed and its comparison with the enzyme levels obtained in free-cells cultures (control). In general, the enzyme production was enhanced when the fungus was immobilized on PUR. Foams with open cells were superior for Lac production than closed cell foams, especially when NFs were present in the foam composition. By using foams with wood, cellulose, or modified cellulose as reinforcement fibers, the Lac activity was increased seven-fold in comparison with the case of the control culture. The maximum Lac activity (140 U/L) was obtained in cultures immobilized on the foam reinforced with cellulose. This result is in agreement with the possible induction of the enzyme activity by the lignocellulose present in these foams.31 In the case of LiP production, the effect of the foam structure was not so pronounced, but again the higher enzyme values were obtained in immobilized cultures on the foams reinforced with NF. The highest LiP activity (190 U/L) was obtained in the PUR reinforced with wood, whose levels were more than 10-fold higher than those obtained in free-cell cultures. Table 6.
Enzyme production (laccase and lignin peroxidase) and fungal growth (mg of biomass per PUR piece) in the immobilized PUR materials with closed and open cells reinforced with different NF (none; 9% wood; 9% cellulose; 9% modified cellulose) and comparison with the enzyme production in non-immobilized cultures (free cells).*
Immobilization support Enzyme activity Biomass
Natural fiber Cell Lac (U/L) LiP (U/L) (mg/piece)
None Closed 45.38b 82.80b 42a
Wood Closed 48.65b 170.53e 75b
Cellulose Closed 45.96b 100.32b 80b
Mod. Cellulose Closed 47.54b 110.83c 89c
None Open 58.46c 100.61b 86b
Wood Open 115.85d 190.35f 102c
Cellulose Open 140.00f 157.10d 115c
Mod. Cellulose Open 123.52e 127.50c 100c
Without immobilization support (free cells) 23.34a 48.26a
*
Data represent the means of triplicate. Data with same letter within each column denotes non-significant difference at a 95% confidence level as evidenced by the multiple rank test.

Differences in enzyme production may be attributed not only to the foams’ composition but also to the dissimilar levels of fungus colonization. The mean amount of the mycelium attached to closed cell foams (71 mg of mycelium per foam piece) was lower than that attained on open cell foams (100 mg of mycelium per foam piece) (Table 6).

In order to deeper analyze the microorganism colonization pattern on foams, the fungal colonized PUR were observed by SEM imaging. After immobilization and enzyme production cycles, the foam pieces were dried and cut at 1.5 - and 3-mm depth. SEM images of the surface and 1.5 and 3 mm depth at a magnification of ×50 were evaluated (Figure 7). The number of the cells colonized by the fungus at each foam depth was counted, and average colonization was calculated as the percentage of the cells colonized per total number of foam cells. Graphs in Figure 7 show a comparison of the results obtained in open and closed cell PURs. All materials were heavily colonized on the surface, but the colonization in depth followed the different pattern in the two main structures tested (open and closed cells). The colonization of all NF-containing materials was evident up to a 3-mm depth in open cell PUR. In closed cell PUR, the growth of fungi at a 3-mm depth was detected only in the PUR without NF and the modified cellulose containing PUR foam. In general, open cell foams were better penetrated by the fungus than closed cell foams. The presence of natural fibers in open cells, especially cellulose and modified cellulose, also led to a more pronounced colonization in depth. This was not the case in closed cell materials whose penetration was higher in non-containing fiber PUR and modified fiber containing PUR. These results support the higher values of the enzyme production and biomass attachment obtained in open cell materials than in closed cell materials. For microorganism immobilization, it is advisable to use an immobilization support that can be colonized in the whole structure. This leads to higher biomass available for enzyme production during the production cycle. Consequently, the higher the colonization in depth the better the enzyme production is expected to be. Hence, open cells materials loaded with natural fibers showed to be superior for fungus immobilization than closed cell materials. Figure 7.
Colonization of PUR by P. flavido-alba. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) study of the penetration of the fungus inside PUR and evaluation of the colonization percentages at different depths.

Carriers for microorganism immobilization can be improved by modifying their structure in such a way that the colonization of a microorganism is facilitated. In addition, some microorganisms may penetrate the whole structure of the carrier because it is able to break the material by mechanical or enzymatic mechanisms. Hence, it is important to know the mechanism of microorganism colonization to improve the material characteristics for immobilization.

In this work, we analyzed SEM images of P. flavido-alba colonized materials to elucidate the colonization mechanism (Figure 8). Colonization of closed cell PUR was mainly performed through breakage areas of foams. It was also noticed that big cells were more often colonized by the fungus than smaller ones, which is likely because they are more easily breakable and thus the fungus may penetrate better. Open cells colonization seems to occur through natural holes of the network, so these holes may facilitate the fungus spread out in the whole structure of the material (Figure 8). This may explain the higher fungal biomass and enzyme activities’ values obtained in open cell foams. There was no evidence of the breakage of PUR cell walls by the fungus mycelium. Figure 8.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of PUR with closed (a–c) and open cells (d–f) showing fungal colonization on the surface (a, d) and details of the colonization pattern in 3-mm depth cut pieces; (b) colonization through the breakage areas; (c) big cells preferentially colonized; (e) and (f) cells colonization through holes in open cells.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Polyol synthesis, based on TO, is an environmentally friendly process with low energy consumption, and the obtained polyols are prospective to substitute those synthesized from petrochemical raw materials. The maximum concentration of the renewable material (TO) in ready PUR is 27%. The content of the renewable raw material in the foam formulations filled with NF could reach 32%.

Compressive strength and Young’s modulus for light weight foams decrease with increasing filler content. By using specific surfactants, it is possible to obtain open cell foams, promising as an immobilization support for microorganisms.

The results reported in this paper show the possibility of using TO PUR foams reinforced with natural fibers as an immobilization support for Lac and LiP production by P. flavido alba. Further studies are needed to optimize the enzyme production and to elucidate whether a process applying a repeated-batch culturing method can be developed for large-scale production of enzymes.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the European Community FP7 grant FORBIOPLAST No.KBBE-212239.
